author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Ashanti's mom nauseated while reading texts from stalker
text:
Alec Tabak/for New York Daily News Tina Douglas testified against her daughter Ashanti’s stalker on Thursday in court. Alec Tabak/for New York Daily News Ashanti Shequoiya Douglas testified in the trial of Devar Hurd, who allegedly stalked her. ANDREW GOMBERT/EPA Tina Douglas said she was "scared" and "thought that he could harm my daughter (pictured) as well as my family because he continued" and she "had heard he had a gun when he was arrested." Previous Next Enlarge He just wouldn't go away.
Ashanti's manager mom was sickened Thursday as she scanned 2009 photos and text messages from the witness stand, missives that were sent by her famous daughter's longtime stalker.
Family matriarch Tina Douglas was the unlucky recipient of Devar Hurd's twisted communications after he scored her cell phone number, apparently from the singer's record label.
The texts and calls — meant to get to her daughter — made Douglas visibly upset as she was asked to review them in front of the jury.
"Disgusting," the “momanger” muttered as she flipped through a binder filled with pages of depraved texts.
One was a photo of Ashanti's car parked in midtown where she was performing in "The Wiz" on Broadway.
"Shany baby i saw u parked yesterday when i showed up to the wiz. I just woke up about to bust a fat nut to your concert performance from," the sicko wrote, alongside the creepy photo signaling that he was near her.
In another vile message, he sent a picture of himself ejaculating.
The older messages were the basis for his conviction that year on stalking and related charges.
Hurd was sentenced to two years behind bars and was given strict court orders to refrain from any contact with the Douglases.
But upon his release, he was right back at it, prosecutors say.
Jefferson Siegel/New York Daily News Devar Hurd violated a restraining order by tweeting at Ashanti and her sister. Susan Watts/New York Daily News Hurd was previously sentenced to two years behind bars and was given strict court orders to refrain from any contact with the Douglases. Previous Next Enlarge He sent a number of tweets to Ashanti and her sister Kenashia, and also went to an event Kenashia was running, posing with her for a photo.
Tina Douglas said she discovered that Hurd was still actively chasing her family when she was at her birthday party at Philippe Chow in Manhattan and her daughters learned he'd been tweeting at them.
"Ashanti brought it to me and I was so upset I immediately called the authorities," Douglas said.
"I was nauseated. I couldn't even finish my meal — it just like started all over again," she added.
Douglas said she was "scared" and "thought that he could harm my daughter as well as my family because he continued" and she "had heard he had a gun when he was arrested."
"I just didn't want to take any chances," she said, explaining that she promptly called a detective she knew and the Manhattan District Attorney's office.
Ashanti and her sister are also expected to testify Thursday.
The delusional defendant argued in his opening statement Wednesday that Ashanti was just mad at him because he thought he was a "two-timer."
The singer never had any connection to Hurd, who fancies himself a music industry player.
